document.title: Washington, DC K-12 Social Studies Standards Revised Standards

1CD8D66E919E423CA144CE51B2D8E9C9.description:
Analyze the characteristics and causes of at least one contemporary issue facing the global community, compare proposals
for addressing the issue, and propose a course of action for making change.

32DCA3F0AB6F41F4B308C210FB43A1E9.description: Use maps to examine global trade markets and to evaluate the spatiality of global supply chains.

18C3A03454404BF4890F7EA25C3EF7BF.description: Evaluate the credibility of online sources and claims about climate change using strategies like lateral reading.

602547571754460494A8CB0FC150D1C8.description:
Identify and explain the human causes and results of climate change, including on species extinction, and compare the
responses of at least three individuals, groups, or governments around the world.

906E12844F3A456280578FD5B53442B1.description:
Evaluate the positive and negative effects of globalization, and the differing impact of globalization on at least three
regions.

FCEBBD76B6544BD9A957E42BFE4C1E53.description: Analyze the various causes of globalization, including advancements in communication and technology.

1A15007C48CB40049FF2CB7D07AA8719.description:
In this driving concept, students synthesize their understanding of world geography and contemporary global issues. By
examining international and supranational organizations and systems, students will return to the study of power and bias that
was the foundation for the course. Students will explore real world examples of the role these systems play in modern events,
and further consider ways to take action as a global citizen.

D7E7A167C1264FD5ABA2FD8A9CD639DF.description: Driving Concept 8: Thinking and Acting Globally

77BDA95F915043FFAA05B01E2CF65ED5.description:
Identify a Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) and assess options for individual and/or collection options for taking action
to address the causes and impacts of challenges facing a region, city or country in Oceania.

9F7BEE57F99243D19763D860A7BAA783.description:
Explain how changes in transportation and communication technology influence the connections between people and
affect the spread of idea/or cultural practice within Oceania and between Oceania and other regions.

A18817F74DCA41A193F3065A0986531E.description:
Analyze the reasons for, and consequences of, the migration of people within, from, and/or to at least one region or
country within Oceania over time, and assess the impact of migration on the region, with specific attention to the role of climate
change on migration from Oceania.

1380531AFF96474A8398AC88CFD36825.description: Analyze the impact of climate change on at least one region, country, or city within Oceania.

21E336975C03402394C6BEBF370F93B6.description:
Use physical, cultural, and economic maps to draw regions on Oceania and compare these to the existing region's economic
communities.

5E1F36B9FE9E4F549A1521F340B43D22.description:
Analyze maps of Oceania that represent a variety of environmental (landforms, bodies of water, natural resources) and
cultural characteristics (languages, borders, religions, etc.) to assess geographic patterns that make up the continent.

DEB4D6416F3D4102B7975772A5C44ABC.description:
Analyze different geographic representations of Oceania, created by different groups of people over time to support claims
about the history and geography of Oceania.

68C99949F03245AC8F59A7AB9637B5FF.description:
In this driving concept, students analyze the geography of Oceania, and the political, economic, social, and cultural impact of
geography on the people and history of the region. Utilizing a variety of maps, students analyze the role of Oceania in global
economics and history, as well as contextualize contemporary issues within the region. It is recommended that teachers use a
case study approach during this driving concept.

910EDDD6D480483191C96ADAD41B8723.description:
Explain how changes in transportation and communication technology influence the connections between people and
affect the spread of ideas/or cultural practices within North America.

B2B7D152DA454966BB7C49DF69B3B7FD.description:
Analyze cultural, political, and economic forces that impact urbanization in at least one city in North America, and evaluate
the impact of these forces on the structure of that city.

92738CD5FB8F4030B794AE204473A191.description:
Analyze the reasons for, and consequences of, migration of people within, from, and/or to one region or country within
North America over time, and assess the impact of migration on the region.

62609C9E26884AA183155C53261C7FC2.description:
Assess the ways in which changes in land use over time have impacted the economy, ecology, population, exposure to
disease or climate change in one region, country or city within North America.

0C3F31805FA8474DA6F34BEAB4F67543.description:
Analyze maps of North America that represent a variety of environmental (landforms, bodies of water, natural resources)
and cultural characteristics (languages, borders, religions, etc.) to assess geographic patterns on the continent.

E75CB26EAB844173A19F2660D970CCA4.description:
Analyze different geographic representations of North America, created by different groups of people over time to support
claims about North American history and geography.

F865BB7EC231475496621A19E13F8E53.description:
In this driving concept, students continue their regional studies through the geography of North America, with an emphasis on
human environment interactions. Utilizing a variety of maps, students analyze the impact of a changing environment on the
region and the world, as well as contextualize contemporary issues within the region. It is recommended that teachers use a case
study approach during this driving concept.

C1836261A84B40E7818C5DB8E9B937F8.description:
Identify a Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) and assess options for individual and/or collection options for taking action
to address the causes and impacts of challenges facing a region, city or country in Europe.

A2481D812ABB49B2BBE798250EEBA743.description:
Analyze at least one cultural element of a country located in Europe (e.g. art, literature, music, dance, cuisine, philosophy,
religious or political thought), including its local significance and influence on other societies.

0BAA8EEBCA9F4F6EA427C41EF6645549.description:
Analyze cultural, political, and economic forces that impact urbanization in at least one city in Europe and evaluate the
impact of these forces on the structure of that city.

2FE74B13B9FA4212B5AEB5817DFE7483.description:
Analyze the reasons for, and the consequences of, the migration of people within, from, and/or to one region or country
within Europe over time and assess the impact of migration on the region.

222EC90130184F47B02D03D71AE6A676.description:
Assess the ways in which changes in land use over time have impacted the economy, ecology, population, exposure to
disease or climate change in one region, country or city within Europe.

2CC839C0CC664D28AC24DFBC7E3D2D37.description:
Use physical, cultural, and economic maps to draw regions in Europe and compare these to the existing region's economic
communities.

A62EC39FBEE340A59A4D21DB5D735AD7.description:
Analyze maps of Europe that represent a variety of environmental (landforms, bodies of water, natural resources) and
cultural (languages, borders, religions, etc.) characteristics to assess geographic patterns on the continent.

F96A63A023554F148A19FABD68DE2319.description:
Analyze different geographic representations of Europe, created by different groups of people over time to support claims
about European history and geography.

AEFE468825364D46A04101A8D50F93F9.description:
In this driving concept, students analyze the geography of Europe, and the political, economic, social, and cultural impact of
geography on the people and history of Europe. Utilizing a variety of maps, students analyze the role of Europe in global
economics and history, as well as contextualize contemporary issues within the region. It is recommended that teachers use a
case study approach during this driving concept.

1287300E2C264768B195EABCECB938F5.description:
Identify a Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) and assess options for individual and/or collection options for taking action
to address the causes and impacts of challenges facing a region, city or country in Latin America or the Caribbean

9E466A918ABD4C62B9D1DBF77FAC42BF.description:
Analyze at least one cultural element of a country located in Latin America or the Caribbean (e.g. art, literature, music,
dance, cuisine, philosophy, religious or political thought), including its local significance and influence on other societies.

7CE4DFF0E35D409EA3670837F868785F.description:
Analyze cultural, political, and economic forces that impact urbanization in at least one city in Latin America or the
Caribbean and evaluate the impact of these forces on the structure of that city.

124D87B1FBC040869A49445F9D42FB0A.description:
Analyze the reasons for, and consequences of, the migration of people within, from, and/or to one region or country in
Latin America or the Caribbean over time and assess the impact of migration on the region.

DC22F7CE3DF2407EAFE470FDE0988E04.description:
Evaluate the influences of long-term, human-induced climate change on patterns of conflict, cooperation, and migration on
one region, country or city within Latin America or the Caribbean.

F420DFF2BD174DA2BBE9621FD6EDF95E.description:
Assess the ways in which changes in land use over time have impacted the economy, ecology, population, exposure to
disease or climate change in one region, country, or city within Latin American or the Caribbean.

7E8B606FECEA4F2C8560B63C818F7908.description:
Evaluate the reasons for patterns of conflict and cooperation between one region or country within Latin American or the
Caribbean and another region or country.

4FCFA08217184775995DFF7614B8162A.description:
Use physical, cultural, and economic maps to draw regions in Latin America and the Caribbean and compare these to the
existing region's economic communities.

BE82DB062AAD4BAABEC9305A60AB58F8.description:
Analyze maps of Latin America and the Caribbean that represent a variety of environmental (landforms, bodies of water,
natural resources) and cultural (languages, borders, religions, etc.) characteristics to assess geographic patterns on the
continent.

6B2AA7C40DAF414E860FC0F843783957.description:
Analyze different geographic representations of Latin America and the Caribbean, created by different groups of people
over time to support claims about Latin American and Caribbean history and geography.

E279871AFB02495A93E15C495010F252.description:
In this driving concept, students continue their regional studies through the geography of Latin America and the Caribbean, with
an emphasis on how geography drives the economics, history, and civics of the region and impacts contemporary life. Utilizing a
variety of maps, students analyze the role of Latin America and the Caribbean in global economics and history, as well as
contextualize contemporary issues within the region. It is recommended that teachers use a case study approach during this
driving concept.

BEF8880A187F44138843B9C7EF71C6B9.description: Driving Concept 4: Latin America and the Caribbean

AF802E2A8E324383886E5038868A4D6C.description:
Identify a Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) and assess options for individual and/or collection options for taking action
to address the causes and impacts of challenges facing a region, city or country in Asia.

E5AF1EE1BEAC49E7818992CF7ED3E7BD.description:
Analyze at least one cultural element of a country located in Asia (e.g., art, literature, music, dance, cuisine, philosophy,
religious or political thought), including its local significance and influence on other societies.

B0FEFA1512E048ACA7473DAD388FA0C5.description:
Explain how changes in transportation and communication technology have influenced the connections between people
and affected the spread of at least one idea and/ or cultural practices within Asia and between Asia and other regions.

9AD0F785239D4E8DB7E0EA59EF7B2513.description:
Evaluate the reasons for, and the impact of, the migration of people within, from, and/or to one region or country within
Asia over time.

86A32C996575448996E66F10CA7867C2.description: Analyze the impact of climate change on at least one region, country, or city within Asia.

445982BAD57044A8971134610E5B6169.description:
Analyze cultural, political, and economic forces that impact urbanization in at least one city in Asia and evaluate the impact
of these forces on the structure of that city.

FBAB978260B242AAB1BC7415FF47A2D3.description:
Assess how the environmental characteristics of Asia influenced the economic development of at least one region or
country within Asia and the region or country’s role in global trade patterns over time.

C477F76C34C34BE39D4936A5DC922C1B.description:
Assess the ways in which changes in land use over time have impacted the economy, ecology, population, exposure to
disease or climate change in one region, country, or city within Asia.

AD17975088A94208AC4307A90E13FEF0.description:
Evaluate the reasons for patterns of conflict and cooperation between at least one country or region within Asia and
another country or region.

500BDF6B5634451983575E5FB5B27F95.description:
Use physical, cultural, and economic maps to draw regions on the Asian continent and compare these to the existing
regional economic communities.

054F0560A7FC4CCA9B9FDBBD175DDE47.description:
Analyze maps of Asia that represent a variety of environmental (landforms, bodies of water, natural resources) and cultural
(languages, borders, religions, etc.) characteristics to assess geographic patterns on the continent.

0266F84472C743038D5C3309099CBAAB.description:
Analyze different geographic representations of Asia, created by different groups of people over time to support claims
about Asian history and geography.

730767744EF44DA4BD0921E640735664.description:
In this driving concept, students continue their regional studies through the geography of Asia, with an emphasis on regional
diversity. Utilizing a variety of maps, students investigate the role of different regions of Asia in global economics and history, as
well as contextualize contemporary issues within the region. It is recommended that teachers use a case study approach during
this driving concept.

1374D949A27D42F2924A857712E79CDF.description:
Identify a Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) and assess options for individual and/or collection options for taking action
to address the causes and impacts of challenges facing a region, city or country in Africa.

7BE695E106F145219E07C3308E79FE5E.description:
Identify ways that global climate policy could impact equitable access to economic, social, and public health opportunities
for at least one group of people in Africa.

A1936D5C249649CFAC3F68F2220478F0.description:
Analyze at least one cultural element of a country located in Africa (e.g., art, literature, music, dance, cuisine, philosophy,
religious or political thought), including its local significance and influence on other societies.

17B0BEF029324735B89790AB85323A98.description:
Analyze cultural, political, and economic forces that impact urbanization in at least one city in Africa, and evaluate the
impact of these forces on the structure of that city.

9EB532969B934860850C888D538B85FF.description:
Analyze geographic data to explain the reasons for the voluntary and forced migration of people within, from, and/or to at
least one country, region, or city within Africa over time, and analyze the development of the African diaspora.

0223F96162454948B75F1D61F313E83E.description:
Explain how population distribution, natural resources, and the history of at least one country or region within Africa have
impacted changes in land use over time.

7F952F6CC4514DB7A0FF28312289D559.description: Evaluate the impact of climate change on people in at least one region, country, or city within Africa.

193457FB45BA4B60B2578171270FC540.description:
Evaluate the reasons for patterns of conflict and cooperation between at least one country or region within Africa and
another country or region , including the impact of colonialism.

15C671A3B48E4489A974CC85A024C30E.description:
Use physical, cultural, and economic maps to draw regions on the African continent and compare these to the existing
region's economic communities.

535924485CBC48679B2300188FCA4567.description:
Analyze maps of Africa that represent a variety of environmental (landforms, bodies of water, natural resources) and cultural
characteristics (languages, borders, religions, etc.) to assess geographic patterns on the continent.

C94437CBBB774D818C443E001611369D.description:
Analyze different geographic representations of Africa, created by different groups of people over time to support claims
about African history and geography.

B85EDD7C7AB34B83AF5B29415AFEFB74.description:
Through this driving concept, students build on their geography skills, analyzing the geography of Africa, and the political,
economic, social, and cultural impact of geography on the people and history of Africa. Through this exploration, students evaluate the diverse regions within Africa. For this driving concept, Africa will serve as a case study for analyzing how generations
of ingenuity contributed to the cultural and intellectual diffusion of ideas around the world. It is recommended that teachers use
a case study approach during this driving concept.

9F4ABA7F28334184966998D3830D2AF9.description:
Evaluate the strengths and limitations of different geographic tools, data sets, and sources for understanding the lived
experiences of individuals in different parts of the world.

84B32E8896EB4F17B85E4CBD8A93538D.description:
Explain how terms and language used to describe different regions and nations can influence our understanding of those
places and the people who live there.

763DD605E4B447F682BF237DCCECDC3B.description:
Describe the purpose, creation, evolution, and impact of international borders, and evaluate the impact of the creation of a
specific border.

523F699AE7904DB181A4FA4CB5CBBF58.description:
Evaluate the ways in which continents are divided, and develop a claim about the strengths and limitations of the current
approach.

00AB3E4326F94D52A31DE09EDE5578E2.description: Analyze how the environment and physical geography shape human behaviors and identities.

90445D30368D4790A410EF363C938C7A.description:
Analyze the impact of the perspective of common map projections on widespread understanding of world geography, and
explain how maps can convey a point of view.

8D580DFA2402412697F7038C1FF0E0FE.description:
Through this driving concept, students analyze the history of maps and mapping and the ways that the discipline of geography is
used to express and maintain power. Students will assess what gives a location a sense of “place,” as well as how humans and
the environment interact to change each other over time. Teachers should use case studies to evaluate how geography
influences human behavior and the development of communities, as well as how communities change over time. Students will
build on their understanding of geography skills and global history, including their understanding of colonization from
elementary social studies to analyze how geography drives human decision making and impacts daily life.

C40974F67EB84D3DBE3BCE6A511C1F03.description: Driving Concept 1: The Power of Maps
